title: 104_s32
content: The text introduces a new tax credit for producing oil and gas from new wells and marginal wells under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a credit amount of $3 per barrel of qualified crude oil production and 50 cents per 1,000 cubic feet of qualified natural gas production, with reductions as oil and gas prices increase. The tax credit amount is determined based on the reference price for the previous calendar year, with adjustments for inflation after 1995. The tax credit amount is determined based on the reference price for the previous calendar year, with adjustments for inflation after 1995. The reference price is defined as the annual average wellhead price per 1,000 cubic feet for all domestic natural gas and qualified crude oil production. The tax credit is based on the reference price for the previous year, adjusted for inflation. Qualified natural gas production includes domestic crude oil from marginal or new wells, with limitations on production amounts to qualify for the credit. The tax credit for qualified natural gas production includes reductions for crude oil produced from new wells. Proportionate reductions apply for short taxable years or wells not in production for the entire year. The tax credit for qualified natural gas production includes reductions for crude oil produced from marginal wells, which are domestic wells with production treated as marginal under specific criteria. The limitations for marginal wells are proportionately reduced based on the number of days in production compared to the total days in the taxable year. The term 'barrel equivalent' refers to a conversion ratio of 6,000 cubic feet of natural gas to 1 barrel of crude oil for wells with average daily production not exceeding 25 barrel equivalents and producing water at a rate of at least 95 percent of total well effluent. The definition of 'new well' applies to domestic wells drilled after December 31, 1994, and terms like 'crude oil', 'natural gas', 'domestic', and 'barrel' are defined as per section 613A(e). The tax credit for crude oil and natural gas production is determined based on the taxpayer's revenue interest in the production compared to all operating interest owners. The credit can only be claimed on production attributable to the holder of an operating interest as defined in section 614(d). The tax credit for crude oil and natural gas production is determined based on the taxpayer's revenue interest in the production compared to all operating interest owners. The credit can only be claimed on production attributable to the holder of an operating interest as defined in section 614(d). The credit is treated as a business credit under section 38(b) of the tax code, and can be allowed against regular and minimum tax. The tax credit for oil and gas production is subject to special rules under subsection (c) of section 38 of the tax code. These rules require separate application of the credit under sections 38 and 39, with limitations on certain aspects of the credit. The tax credit for oil and gas production is subject to special rules under subsection (c) of section 38 of the tax code. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year shall be reduced by the oil and gas production credit. The term 'oil and gas production credit' refers to the credit allowable under subsection (a) by reason of section 45C(a). A conforming amendment is made to section 38(c)(2)(A)(ii) by including the oil and gas production credit. Coordination with Section 29 is amended to allow the taxpayer to elect the application of the credit. At the taxpayer's election, a change is made to the tax code by adding a new item to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to production after the date of the enactment of this Act.
